$BTC When the market is falling like today ‚Üí whatever you do, don't open a short position!
Many people think BTC will go straight to 80k or 70k and will short massively.
Wrong. Even if it does go there, it won't go in a straight line: it will first chase out all the shorts with sharp upward spikes.
In a bear market, the market is heavily manipulated: whales know you're going to short, so they liquidate you every time.
My advice: stop shorting until there's real regulation or at least a less manipulated phase. Otherwise, you'll lose every time.

ON THE POSITIVE SIDE: Key liquidity pockets have already been taken out. Price reacted immediately toward a major resistance zone, showing strong demand and momentum.  ON THE NEGATIVE SIDE: Today‚Äôs move created a CME gap around $89.4K, which the market often returns to fill once traditional trading reopens. So while the surge is a encouraging sign that market activity is picking up, traders should stay cautious of a possible pullback early in the week as the CME gap gets addressed.  If Bitcoin can break through this current resistance zone afterward, the path toward $100k becomes much clearer and overall sentiment could shift quickly once those levels start giving way.

$BTC  Is It Really Worth Creating a Cryptocurrency? Can It Be Truly Profitable?  Creating a cryptocurrency requires investment, and if the project succeeds early on, the owner expects returns. But how does a typical crypto creator behave behind the scenes?  It usually begins with generating FOMO‚Äîthe fear of missing out. The owner pushes the price upward, creating hype and attracting investors. Once the price reaches the peak, the owner locks in the liquidity, trapping investors who bought at the top.  With investors stuck, the owner begins creating new liquidity points during the downtrend, because these zones are essential for the owner to continue selling. Eventually, the owner establishes the bottom, since they need to accumulate at the lowest price possible.  After accumulating, the owner orchestrates a rally from the bottom back to the main liquidity resistance. This ensures that no investor ‚Äúmisses‚Äù the upward movement. When buyers rush into these liquidity levels, the owner sells again.  If the chart breaks upward, whales and large investors replace the trapped earlier holders. Some of them exit at breakeven; others leave with small profits.  Then comes the silent phase: while investors try to predict the next top, the owners discreetly sell without raising suspicion. They push the price slowly down toward the next liquidity support zone below. Fear takes over, causing small investors to panic-sell at low prices, which creates new liquidity for the owner.  After that, the chart collapses again, trapping both the buyers at the top and those who bought into liquidity zones. The owner eventually returns to the accumulation area at the bottom‚Äîthe same zone they defined from the start............If you want to see part 2 of this story, it will be in the comment below, remembering that this is a story.

üö® JUST IN: Fed Ends QT and Shifts to Modest Treasury Purchases to Keep Reserves ‚ÄúAmple

The Federal Reserve officially ended quantitative tightening on December 1, 2025, and is now letting its balance sheet stabilize (and potentially grow very slowly) through technical reinvestments and possible Treasury bill purchases.

Here‚Äôs what actually happened (no hype, just facts):

Key Points :

- QT is over. The Fed is no longer reducing its balance sheet.

- Starting now, all maturing agency MBS principal (~$15‚Äì25B/month recently) will be reinvested into Treasury securities (mostly T-bills).

- Maturing Treasuries will be fully rolled over instead of capped at $5B/month.

- Combined, this implies ~$20‚Äì30B/month of gross Treasury additions in the near term ‚Äî not new QE, just replacing runoff and offsetting growth in currency + other liabilities.

- Fed officials have explicitly said they may buy additional T-bills if reserves fall below ‚Äúample‚Äù levels (current target zone appears 

~8‚Äì11% of GDP). No fixed $45B/month figure has been announced or confirmed by the Fed.
Rate Path
- Markets are pricing an 85%+ chance of a 25 bps cut at the December 9‚Äì10 FOMC meeting (taking fed funds to 3.75‚Äì4.00%).
- Powell & Co. continue to emphasize the dual mandate: maximum employment + 2% inflation.

Crypto Takeaway
Bitcoin is trading ~$91,300 today. The combination of:

- No more QT drain
- Likely December rate cut
- Stabilizing/gradually rising reserves

‚Ä¶is unambiguously positive for risk assets and liquidity-sensitive markets like crypto.

This isn‚Äôt 2020-style ‚Äúunlimited QE,‚Äù but it does remove a major headwind and adds a mild tailwind ‚Äî exactly the kind of environment that has historically fueled the next leg up in BTC and alts.
